publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Qizil Miŋ-Öyduring T III MQ 69, T III MQR 97, T III MQ 49

seg.seg: ... from the four directions (?) he saw those who were to be saved ... [how they ... not ...]

p.note: According to 239, the script type is ‘‘old”; but in fact the only archaic-shaped sign is the rare 〈śa〉, otherwise we only find standard-shaped ones; to be sure, some signs have an italic-type look, i.e., slightly archaic appearance; cf. 265.

list.item: a1 yy[ā] cce ṣṣ aiknesa – [p·] ceṃts ñäś ce_u – – – nt _p_alskomeṃ yärpo śamnā – [ts·] oko _m_asket_rä [80-]9 klye_uṣtr āpa /// a2 ne_uṣ ṭ[e](pa)ṅkarsa [p]ūdñäktesa ṣūkt u[ppā] – – – _t_aṅwsā sumati t[o]n n(o) uppālnta kṣāttre mt āṣtsā pū(dñ)äkte – /// a3 re ponta – ṅ_k_a= rām_t_a ○ akāśne tusa k(akāc)cu [p]ly(e)_u[sa] su ke_ucä ñeñmu kektseñ\ yäprerne o_t\ ś·a – (–) – /// a4 nāṣṣa karpa no ○ k[eṃ]ntsa _ṣ_añ [m](a)[t]s(i) reksa p[ū]dñäktentse tāṣṣatsisa katkemāne suma /// a5 lyka [_t_aṅwsa] no ke_ucä ○ katkemane pū(d)ñ(ä)ktemeṃ [ṣa]māññe ot rītāte āśc ··rtkā·e ·ā·e /// a6 rne _k_alpoṣṣepi _t_aṅwsā yärke yāmṣāre ś[ā]k[k]yamuni ślek pudñäkte /// a7 [_ṣ_aṃ] ly[u]kā-me śtwāra kacenmeṃ lyaka t_säl[p]elye[n] _m_akte cey mā – /// b1 rsaso ·änt nai p_t_anmameṃ yärpo _ṣ_añ kektseñmeṃ ce yärposa _p_arlle s[t]e /// b2 ktseñe [_m_a]ntak yarke alā_l_atte yāmi śaumo p(_t_a)nmane k_use tu _k_artse /// b3 khwa śv·lmeṃ nirvvāṃ○ṣṣeṃ _ṣ_armtsā śarīrntats\ po tu _k_allālle cintaman(i) wm· m· – /// b4 winās[k]e(_u) _t_añ cā○_k_k_a_r\ ṣotri (p)er(n)eñc paiyn(e) • _t_añ krentewna epyac klyormeṃ wakītsana • _r_am_t_a /// b5 cek wärñai – aknātsaññe kwīpesa no ·i – – ma_r\ yonwā ñäś(\) ce śāmñe cämel taññe _ṣ_armtsa$ā /// b6 kektseñ y[ā]twa indrintasa : aknātsañ[ñ]e (–) – ·ts· ṅke kr_ui mā skāyau ente nta kca _ṣ_p\ ñäskemar tañä\ e(rsna) [l]k[ā]ts(i) /// b7 _m_akte ke _ṣ_p_a ñäk[t]e[ṃs ña]kta te mänt w[ñ]ā – (–) – ktau ra _ś_aktāllye kw(r)i – ·ṣ· ṣene • nem[c]ek tumeṃ wrotse oko _p_a ///

Alternative classifications:
Peyrotarchaic I
Malzahnarchaic ~ standard
TamaiII-1 (600-700)
Tamai-C14–

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
b1 Know [pl.] [this]: «Thus (the beings) have to get the merit from the stūpas through the merit from their own bodies»! 355
b6 If I don't try to drive away foolishness, then I [may] never wish to see your appearance. 699

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-3 Man hört (in) einem Ava(dāna): "Einstmals (warf) Sumati sieben Lotusblüte(n) aus Liebe auf den Buddha Dīpaṅkara. Diese Lotusblüten aber (standen) wie ein Schirm sämtlich auf dem Haupte (des) Buddha ... 220
a5 Mit Liebe sah er [scil. Sumati] aber auf, erfreut, [und] erstrebte alsdann das Mönchtum vom Buddha. 151
a5 Erfreut begehrte er [scil. Sumati] alsdann vom Buddha das Mönchtum [und] schor [sich] den Kopf. 324
b4 Ich verehre deine beiden radgekennzeichneten glänzenden Füße. 415
b5 Voller Scham [wtl. mit Scham] aber (bekenne(?)) ich [meine] Unwissenheit. 415
b6 ...den Körper hielt ich durch die Sinnesorgane im Zaum. 26


additional classification A1

On the verso side, there is a lot of additional text that has been ignored and needs to be dealt with: (1) a (probably) vertically written line along the left margin with dots leading into b4; at least 2 signs below the end of b6; (3) half a line below the end of b7. –Martin (Tue, 2019-05-14, 02:26:16 (CEST))

I added all the metrical notation, of which there were none at all. I changed transcription a2 mt to «ra»mt and a5 ke_ucä to ke_uc«†ä» (as did Sieg & Siegling). I doubt the reconstruction b1 (onolmentsä), because it extends over a caesura. Better would be something like (– onolments), instead. –Martin (Wed, 2020-03-18, 23:07)

According to [[TochSprR(B) II]]: 239, the script type is ‘‘old”; but in fact the only archaic-shaped sign is the rare 〈<u>śa</u>〉, otherwise we only find standard-shaped ones; to be sure, some signs have an italic-type look, i.e., slightly archaic appearance; cf. [[Malzahn 2007a]]: 265.
T III MQ 69, T III MQR 97, T III MQ 49
